thread.title: NMSU looks to Mexico to boost declining enrollment
thread.title_full: NMSU looks to Mexico to boost declining enrollment | Albuquerque Journal News

author: Lauren Villagran / Journal Staff Writer - Las Cruces Bureau
title: NMSU looks to Mexico to boost declining enrollment
text:
Copyright © 2015 Albuquerque Journal
LAS CRUCES – Faced with falling enrollment at home, New Mexico State University is pitching itself to foreign students – especially south of the border.
NMSU administrators were in Chihuahua City on Thursday to participate in a binational panel on higher education, where they highlighted recent accords with Mexican universities designed to attract students to NMSU’s graduate programs.
The visit was part of the weeklong goodwill and economic development mission of a delegation of more than a dozen New Mexico legislators. Higher Education Secretary Barbara Damron was scheduled to speak on the panel, and her counterpart, Chihuahua State Education Secretary Marcelo Gonzalez Tachiquin, was slated to discuss joint agreements.
“We believe that we are just an ideal place for Mexican students to come,” said Dan Howard, NMSU executive vice president and provost, in a phone call from Chihuahua City. “Our natural partner is Mexico, and we need to do more to bring more of these students to New Mexico State.”
NMSU President and former Gov. Garrey Carruthers has said he wants to increase the percentage of graduate students on campus to 20 percent of total enrollment from 14 percent currently, and he sees a fertile market in Mexico and China in particular. He canceled plans to travel to Chihuahua this week due to illness.
This fall, roughly 8 percent, or 1,288 of NMSU’s 15,490 students are international students. They come primarily from Kuwait, Mexico, India, Saudi Arabia and Brazil – in that order. Half are enrolled in graduate programs.
NMSU already boasts the highest percentage of foreign students at a New Mexico public university, according to spokesman Justin Bannister. He said University of New Mexico has roughly the same number of foreign students, but with a fall enrollment of more than 27,000 students, the overall percentage is less.
Enrollment on NMSU’s main campus has declined over the past five years, from a peak of 18,024 students in fall 2011. The enrollment peak came during the recession, as people lost jobs and sought degrees. As the economy has improved, the opposite has occurred and more people are heading to the job market instead of class.
At the same time, New Mexico’s population is not growing, and the state’s institutions of higher education are all jockeying for a static number of high school graduates, Carruthers has said.
NMSU has been strengthening ties with Mexican institutions.
NMSU struck an accord with the university Tecnológico Nacional de México earlier this summer, potentially opening slots for 300 engineering graduate students next year. Later this month, NMSU and the Autonomous University of Chihuahua will hold a two-day innovation and entrepreneurism event called CampusLink.
It may help that there are Aggies in Chihuahua state government: “There are several (Mexican) legislators who we have met who are Aggies,” Howard said.
The Chihuahua trip is all about “getting to know each other better, understanding capabilities and finding opportunities for partnership,” he said.
